item.title: As Russia and China look on, pondering whether Americans can still pull themselves together in a great national endeavor, they may not be too discouraged https://t.co/0824B6UuPV

“They added this new piece that we haven’t really done before.” @john_sipher talks to our “Checks and Balance” podcast about the tactic to declassify and publicly release intelligence—a recent addition to America’s playbook https://t.co/mrCBARXvKl https://t.co/2AES3VgQBE

Russian troops appear to be attempting to encircle the capital.
Germany said it would supply 1,000 anti-tank weapons and 500 Stinger surface-to-air missiles.
NATO’s secretary-general said that the it would deploy elements of its response force.
Catch up https://t.co/ft7cJAWINN
Ukrainian refugees are more to the Polish government’s liking than Syrians and Afghans. It began building a fence along its border to keep them out in 2015 https://t.co/QBI9pO1DjF
The Kremlin has been bracing itself for the possibility of being cut off from SWIFT since 2014, when America floated the idea as punishment for the invasion of Crimea https://t.co/19r4Tp3jkx
To what extent could liquefied natural gas replace piped Russian gas as a source of energy for Europe? We explain https://t.co/g4iOobD0WE
Unlike the Trump administration when it went after Huawei, the Biden administration has consulted allies and affected companies ahead of time. This makes the net tighter https://t.co/fFt9bepxJm
Alexei Navalny displays the extraordinary bravery of an ordinary man. Read about the making of Russia’s political prisoner number one, from @1843mag https://t.co/MqOQPysuNH

♦️ Russia’s siege of Kyiv intensifies.
♦️ Nearly 116,000 Ukrainians have fled their homes, the UN estimates.
♦️ Five eastern European countries said they would ban Russian airlines from using their airspace and landing at their airports.
Catch up on the latest developments👇
Europe gets around a quarter of its energy from gas. In 2019 Russia supplied over 40% of that gas https://t.co/I2wCEALZr5
In the coming days NATO might muster the unanimous vote needed to deply its 40,000-strong Response Force for the first time in its history https://t.co/5dkECmPzEE
Indians picked up around 340 tonnes of gold in the last quarter of 2021, equivalent to the weight of five Indian elephants every week https://t.co/TvDQdd9UgK
China’s latest five-year plan stipulates that it should produce 70% of the chips it consumes by 2025, up from less than 20% last year https://t.co/qOd8Z8h2Zr
It is a shame that the unity America has mustered in this circumstance, welcome though it is, is not more impressive https://t.co/1VCW2yHPNu
Russian (like Soviet) military doctrine calls for multiple “echelons” of forces, with heavy forces kept in reserve https://t.co/nj1Yi2b48P

Since the modern era of globalisation began, no major economy has been cut off from the global financial system, and the risk of broader contagion across markets cannot be ruled out https://t.co/VMXh5VzNbp
Since the invasion began, trains arriving from Ukraine at Przemysl, the first stop on the Polish side of the border, have been carrying as many as 600 people at a time https://t.co/rmx8cui1uR
European security will be reshaped by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. The continent’s eastern flight paths already have been https://t.co/DlJUETr4Nu
Western officials play down the idea that Vladimir Putin would attack NATO. But Russia is paranoid and hostile: they have to plan for the possibility of aggression https://t.co/0c3WQFwkQM

Russia’s war in Ukraine is likely to be Europe's most intense conflict since the second world war.
What might happen next? And what will this war mean for the world?
Our experts answer your questions 👇
Western intelligence assessments have long suggested that Russian forces will seek the “decapitation” of Ukraine's government and the installation of a puppet regime https://t.co/lwQtKKRRo7

Economic action is the weapon of choice. One obvious move would be to cut Russian banks’ access to SWIFT. But for now the measure remains off the list of sanctions outlined by the West https://t.co/SftKeOMXwF
The sanctions will probably bite lightly at first. Only later will they clench their jaws https://t.co/X1TBMzQLYK

As Russia invades, millions of Ukrainians are fearing for their future. What is happening on the ground, and comes next? The Economist's correspondent, Richard Ensor, reports from Kyiv https://t.co/xW41jK0uQD

♦️ America, Britain and 25 other countries pledge more military aid to Ukraine.
♦️ Russia’s defence ministry claims to have captured the city of Melitopol.
♦️ At least 198 people have been killed so far by Russia’s invasion, Ukraine’s health ministry says.
Catch up quickly👇
A former British Army officer warns against drawing too many lessons from the first two days of fighting https://t.co/5BauH3yaxW
Russia’s leading opposition figure has endured ignominy, imprisonment and poisoning over the course of his political career. He isn’t finished yet https://t.co/ovpeVe9ayz
The protesters’ faces were crestfallen, gripped by dismay and grief. And they were met with brutality https://t.co/VhoNNg7jr0

For America and Europe, Vladimir Putin’s invasion marks the definitive end of the post-cold-war thaw. Instead there will be a return to open military competition and great-power confrontation https://t.co/rF4voJ00mg

♦️ More shelling and heavy fighting were reported throughout Kyiv.
♦️ Volodymyr Zelensky suggested that France would support cutting Russia off from SWIFT.
♦️ Meta barred Russian state media from running ads on its platforms.
Catch up on the latest developments 👇
In the fighting and the misery that is to come, much Ukrainian and Russian blood will be spilled. Every drop of it will be splattered on his hands https://t.co/GedUe4lnRw
The invasion might not cause a global economic crisis today—but it will change how the world operates for decades to come https://t.co/sV3UodPMGE

“If bodybags start coming back in large numbers to Russia, that will be hard for him.” On “The Economist Asks” podcast, @zannymb talks to @AnneMcElvoy about Vladimir Putin’s motives, and how his people will react to Russia’s historic attack on Ukraine https://t.co/sBXqjUF6Bj https://t.co/Vl2CNS38Aj
How Gazprom helps the Kremlin put the squeeze on Europe https://t.co/xuWo6cfoIG
Vladimir Putin was doubtless promised a short war by his generals; he has failed to achieve a lightning one https://t.co/J3XQC4bseU
Though the target of Vladimir Putin’s tirade is Ukraine, the former Soviet republics now in NATO—Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania—have cause for alarm https://t.co/iJn0HU1JYX

Russia’s war in Ukraine is likely to be Europe's most intense conflict since the second world war. What might happen next? And what will this war mean for the world?
Our experts answer your questions 👇 https://t.co/iSTPl9nIxH https://t.co/ZyPY6vpvf8
Several thousand people, mostly young, poured onto the streets in Moscow holding signs condemning the war unleashed against their brothers and sisters in Ukraine https://t.co/COMWlyWPLB
Those arriving in Poland from Ukraine will be provided with temporary accommodation, according to a government website https://t.co/kJ5nkgkA2t
All but three of the 115 justices who have served on the Supreme Court since 1789 have been white; all but five have been men https://t.co/6TZKDvXVuj
Despite being outgunned and outnumbered, Ukraine reportedly inflicted more casualties in 24 hours than Russia suffered over eight years of engagements in Syria https://t.co/8c3QTNQCxS

“If bodybags start coming back in large numbers to Russia, that will be hard for him.” On “The Economist Asks” podcast, @zannymb talks to @AnneMcElvoy about Vladimir Putin’s motives, and how Russia’s people will react to his historic attack on Ukraine https://t.co/9u42l1k4FL https://t.co/hoTeCpSISM
Even though most Republican lawmakers have endorsed Joe Biden’s position on Ukraine, they are straining to find reasons to criticise him https://t.co/sSGB68YihV
Russia approached the Ukraine’s capital from Belarus along several axes, both east and west of the capital, in a pincer movement. Not all were successful https://t.co/RqZHVnFTWr
In the long term, the war will accelerate the division of the world into economic blocs https://t.co/SFodshFm2B
The charismatic Ukrainian president has cast himself on social media as a gritty and determined wartime leader https://t.co/JUkFZFixfK
A full-scale war will push democracies together and destabilise a global order in which China has thrived https://t.co/eYhGYbfzCb

Nothing about the war in Ukraine was inevitable. It is a conflict entirely of Vladimir Putin’s own making. Our cover story explains why, and how, the world must inflict a heavy price for his aggression https://t.co/dLBLmSBDnF https://t.co/g8TK0KoC4d
Russia’s effective absorption of Belarusian troops means it has a lot of firepower on the edge of the “Suwalki gap”, a strip of land that connects Poland to the Baltic states https://t.co/h2es1PdJRw
The American government is in effect claiming jurisdiction over any person or company in the world that uses American technology to make products for sale in Russia https://t.co/KEl205rSBx
